column39: CNCF is a zoo of different projects that solve different problems. Separately when you want to use them they are great, but to make them work together it is a nightmare. CNCF is missing a platform-like, integration projects that have a goal to integrate those different projects in one stack, and they work with those projects to improve their abilities to integrate. Cloud is complex, it is not enough to give someone a package of lego, lego duplo and building blocks from other vendors, without instruction, expecting they can easily build something out of it. You need project that make sure all those blocks are compatible and work well with each other.
column40: Have a clear process for accepting/rejecting projects, that is always transparently followed and decisions are not made on closed meetings unless some company asked for it explicitly
column41: I basically lost my belief in transparency of TOC work. Kyma was not allowed to present on public meeting. We were not checked in details and advised what has to change or to be done to get accepted. On a private TOC meeting there was a decision we get rejected, and then just communicated in PR, like it is just a usual case. Few hours later, after the decision (it all happened during KubeCon, when before KubeCon I got information that TOC will not have time to discuss the project with them and that we will cover that after KubeCon) one of the TOC members approach the booth and asked us to explain what Kyma is. He asked us what it is even though they already made a decision it is not a good project for CNCF.    Such things make others think TOC is still powered by private business of certain companies and projects are blocked as potential competition. I'm still believe it is not true, but if you treat like this a project from such a large company as SAP, you should take into accoutn that such a company can have long term doubts.

column40: I think the CNCF is moving the right direction. A lot of my answers reflect the current state, but I don't think there's a lot of consistency across SIGs and across TOC members in these processes and involvement.
column41: I'd like to see the TOC standardize on the SIG process. I'd also like clearer governance of SIG leadership - how SIG chairs change over time. I think the TOC is making strides to solve their own scalability problem, BUT for a while it felt stalled halfway through and there are a lot of pieces of this that aren't complete.    I totally understand that we're completing a lot of elections through this cycle. However, I think this exacerbated the symptoms - and the TOC will continue to have elections over time. I think a strong internal focus on getting the TOC and graduation process of projects into a strong engine would be a great focus for 2020, so that future TOC members are able to be quickly onboarded and productive in the TOC environment.

column40: There are a few things.    1. Clearly document processes. I have routinely been in SIG meetings where questions about processes arise and no one, including the SIG chairs, knows the answer to. Sometimes documentation is lacking and sometimes it does not reflect the process. This is a communication problem as people do not know what to expect or how to proceed. This applies to sandbox, incubation, and graduation projects.    2. Have TOC members regularly attend SIG and WG meetings. Unanswerable questions come up regularly and TOC members are not present to hear them.    3. TOC members regularly triage and engage with projects on the TOC GitHub repo. If the TOC is involved where the work is expected to happen around processes and questions it will help the TOC be more engaged and respond more quickly. This is part of how healthy open source projects work when it comes to code. It idea can be played out with the TOC repo.
column41: Listen, become more engaged, try to understand the problems people are having.    Also, be patient with people. Some of the people stuck in the processes have been going through a single process for more than 6 months and are becoming increasingly frustrated.

column39: Data on Kubernetes as opposed to data connected to Kubernetes via CSI was not anticipated by early k8s architects or by leadership of storage SIG.  Even though this pattern has proliferated and adds value to kubernetes at users like the CNCF itself and bloomberg and otherwise furthers the aims of the CNCF we have been treated w/ overt hostility by certain members of the TOC who accuse us of “exploiting” the CNCF for example and lobby against the inclusion of OpenEBS.  Also would recommend a chaos engineering project or two be adopted.
column40: The TOC should police each other and not allow projects in good standing to be accused of exploiting the CNCF without that language being challenged.
column41: Talk to top users about their bottlenecks and opportunities - such as data management - and keep an open mind as they point out unexpected or unanticipated patterns of adoption.

column39: I don't believe that all projects must be under the same foundation. What is important is that if they want to be considered that they are given a fair opportunity. It was disappointing that CNAB was turned away from the CNCF when they wanted to be considered for inclusion but ship has sailed and they are still in the LF.
column40: The process churn over the past 6 months has been confusing as someone considering submitting a new project. Watching projects that have been caught mid-proposal while it has happened has been hard to watch. The new SIG process has felt biased, hostile and unnecessarily dragged out over things that are out of scope of the TOC DD process, and I'm not even involved in the projects in question.     The SIG's are supposed to help the TOC but there needs to be better clarity to the people participating. Some people are in the know about how this works because they attend TOC meetings and "know people" often but not enough of this is communicated to everyone who just show up to meetings as an interested party. It's not written down and they think any question is okay to just throw out at a maintainer and hold up things over.    I really don't want to go through this same process with my own project...
